rows.name: number_line_intro
rows.value: Number paths and number lines make the relationships between numbers more concrete and visible for beginning learners. These paths and lines make a great visual and mental representation for seeing how the numbers fit together.

rows.name: topics_text
rows.value:
**Keep Grounded** The goal of using number paths and number lines is to ground the numerical skills being learned with the meaning of the numbers. It serves no purpose to have your students memorize a collection of mathematical facts if they do not know what they are talking about.

The beginning skills of counting, order, adding and subtracting with small numbers are better learned in visual and tactile ways. Working with number paths and number liines reinforces the size and spacing of the numbers.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
The numbers on cards, paths, and lines should increase from left to right. While number lines should always start at 0 (until negative numbers are encountered), the cards and paths should either start at 0 or 1. 

**Starting at 0:** Starting cards or a path at 0 matches up with the number lines your students will be seeing later on. It allows one to stand on or start at 0, and then count forward from there. It also forms a more natural transition to Counting On - if a student is used to starting at 0 and counting forward, then that is consistent with adding 3 + 2 by starting on the 3 and counting on "4, 5."

**Starting at 1:** If objects being counted are put directly above the number path cards, starting at 1 allows a student to see and experience a 1-1 correspondance of the objects with the cards of the number path.

**100 Chart:** A 100 chart is an additional organized way of showing the numbers to your students; however, the wrapping around of the number line is a bit more abstract. It will be useful as your students progress to larger number ranges, but avoid using these charts too early. For example, adding and subtracting 10 on a 100 chart is very convenient, but if you are not careful to set up place value first, your students will use it as a mindless, meaningless tool.

rows.name: numbered_cards_text
rows.value: Prop up numbered cards on a table or ledge, or paper-clip them to a string. Having an individual card for each number allows for more natural association with numbered cards you may be using for demonstration purposes. It also allows them to be moved around or left out (for activities like "put these in order" or "which one is missing."

rows.name: number_path_text
rows.value: This is a path of sequenced numbers on the ground or in adjacent rectangles on a piece of paper. Students can walk on these to get a physical connection with the numbers and their order.

rows.name: number_line_text
rows.value:
For young children not ready for negative numbers, this is a portion of a line with an endpoint on the left side for 0. It has numbered tick marks extending to the right.

It is a more abstract representation than the other two already described. It is also a more powerful and versatile representation that is essential for modeling larger numbers and numbers with fractional parts.

rows.name: chart_text
rows.value: As your students begin to work with larger number ranges, you will probably want to start making use of 100 chart. These are 10 by 10 charts of the numbers from 1 to 100 or 0 to 99. Your students should be confident with number paths and number lines before using these.

rows.name: text_three_stages
rows.value:
There are three stages associated with many of these tasks. 
* Hold numbered cards or write numbers directly on or above the number path.
* Move away from the number path but still have it visible nearby. 
* Do the activity without the number path being visible.
